title: R42445
content: The most recent multi-year authorization for federal surface transportation programs, SAFETEA-LU, expired in 2009. Since then, programs have operated on extension acts and resolutions due to constrained financial resources. The highway trust fund, funded by highway taxes, has seen declining revenues. Passing a multi-year bill without cutting infrastructure spending, raising the gas tax, or increasing the budget deficit is a key issue in the ongoing debate. The ongoing debate revolves around issues such as alternative finance, tolling, public-private partnerships, project delivery acceleration, and performance management in the context of federal spending distribution among states. The Senate passed MAP-21 on March 14, 2012, reauthorizing surface transportation programs for two years. H.R. 7, the American Energy and Infrastructure Jobs Act, is a five-year bill providing for a total. H.R. 7 is a five-year bill with a total authorization of $260 billion, linking surface transportation reauthorization with provisions for oil and gas production. It includes controversial measures like discontinuing mass transit funding from Highway Trust Fund revenues. The House passed the Surface Transportation Extension Act of 2012, Part II (H.R. 4348) to extend authorizations through FY2012, with additional provisions related to the Keystone XL Pipeline and environmental streamlining. The Senate agreed to an amendment on H.R. 4348, replacing it with the language of MAP-21 to send the measure to conference. Negotiations will involve the substance of H.R. 7 and provisions of the extension bill. Surface transportation reauthorization is complex due to multiple committees involved. The highway trust fund is mainly funded by excise taxes on motor fuels. The Highway Trust Fund (HTF) is funded by excise taxes on motor fuels, with gasoline taxed at 18.4 cents per gallon and diesel at 24.3 cents per gallon. The fund consists of two accounts - highway and mass transit. The highway account receives 15.44 cents of the gasoline tax, while the mass transit account receives 2.86 cents. Due to stagnant fuel tax rates since 1993 and factors like economic slowdown and improved vehicle fuel efficiency, revenues have fallen short. The highway account has required transfers from the general fund to cover shortfalls, with a projected shortfall of $4.6 billion by the end of FY2013 according to the Congressional Budget Office. The Highway Trust Fund faces a yearly gap of $8 to $9 billion through FY2022. The mass transit account is projected to have a shortfall of $1.2 billion by the end of FY2014, increasing to $5 billion by the end of FY2015. Without an increase in fuel taxes, the trust fund will struggle to support transportation spending, leading policymakers to consider new revenue sources or a smaller program. The Federal-Aid Highway Program encompasses various programs administered by FHWA with consistent financial and administrative attributes. The Highway Program is primarily state-run, with state DOTs determining spending and complying with federal guidelines. Federally funded projects require a local matching share, with different percentages for Interstate System and other roads. FHWA manages fund distribution through notifications, apportionment, allocation, and reimbursement processes. The highway program has statutory distribution formulas for reimbursement once a project is approved and work is started. Contract authority allows for obligation without an appropriation, with the federal government legally committing to reimburse states for project costs. Limitation on obligations controls annual spending, and there are formula and discretionary programs for fund allocation among states. Under SAFETEA, federal-aid highway money is apportioned to state DOTs through core formula programs like IM, NHS, STP, HBP, CMAQ, HSIP, and EB. Each program has its own formula factors to determine state funding. The Equity Bonus Program guarantees each state a minimum share of funds regardless of funding formulas, diluting the policy rationales of core program formulas. Some state DOTs argue that programmatic structure limits their use of federal highway funds as they see fit. Smaller discretionary highway programs are also part of the Federal-Aid Highway Program. During SAFETEA, federal transit programs were administered by FHWA and FTA, with different funding mechanisms and rules. Four main programs accounted for 85% of transit funding, with two programs distributing funds by formula. The Urbanized Area Formula Program, the largest program, provided funding to urbanized areas. The Urbanized Area Formula Program in SAFETEA accounts for 41% of authorized transit funding and provides funding to urbanized areas with populations of 50,000 or more. Funds can be used for various expenses including capital, planning, transit enhancements, and operations in urbanized areas with populations of up to 200,000. Fixed Guideway Modernization Program funds, 16% of authorized transit funding, are mainly for the replacement and rehabilitation of transit rail system assets. The New Starts Program, making up 18% of overall authorized transit funding, is available on a competitive basis for new fixed guideway systems and extensions. Congress also enacted a "Small Starts" program to fund projects with a total cost of $250 million or less. The Small Starts projects are funded with $200 million annually from the New Starts authorization. Bus Program funds, 9% of authorized funding, are used to purchase buses and related equipment. Highway transportation is the leading cause of transportation-related fatalities in the US, with federal programs assisting states in improving highway safety. The Department of Transportation (DOT) administers highway safety programs through three agencies: NHTSA for driver behavior and vehicle safety, FMCSA for commercial driver qualifications and vehicle safety, and FHWA for roadway design safety. NHTSA provides grants to states, regulates motor vehicle safety, and requires states to submit highway safety plans to receive federal funds. States must identify safety problems, set goals, and establish performance measures for progress. NHTSA also offers training and technical assistance to states. The Department of Transportation administers highway safety programs through NHTSA, FMCSA, and FHWA. FMCSA promotes commercial vehicle safety through regulation, enforcement, and grant programs. HSIP aims to reduce traffic fatalities by improving roadway design. States receive funding for safety initiatives through various grant programs. The Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP) provides funding to states based on road lane-miles, vehicle miles traveled, and traffic fatalities. States receive a minimum of 0.5% of the program's funding. SAFETEA extended funding guarantees and created budget categories to protect highway and mass transit funds from being reallocated. The Budget Enforcement Act guarantees for highway funding were honored until 2002. The House rule protecting funding levels was eliminated in the 112th Congress. The RABA mechanism adjusts funding based on actual receipts, but Congress has never cut spending despite revenue shortfalls. Recent years saw general fund transfers supplementing the Highway Trust Fund, making RABA calculations moot. However, future reauthorization may consider mechanisms to align spending with receipts. The Budget Control Act requires sequestration of certain funding authorizations if a special joint committee fails to reach an agreement on spending reductions. Exemptions under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 likely mean that sequestration would not significantly reduce surface transportation spending authorized beyond FY2012. Exempted programs include Federal-Aid Highways, Highway Traffic Safety Grants, NHTSA operations, Motor Carrier Safety Operations, Transit Formula and Bus Grants. MAP-21 is a two-year reauthorization bill that would reduce the number of highway programs by two-thirds and make significant changes to the structure, formulas, and funding distribution of the federal highway program. It includes a total authorization of $39.5 billion for FY2012 and $40.5 billion for FY2013, with $400 million allocated for research and education each fiscal year. The bill eliminates individual formula factors and apportions funds to states based on their share of total apportionments and allocations from FY2005-FY2009. This change in programmatic structure reduces federal and congressional influence on project selection. MAP-21 aims to reduce federal and congressional influence on program direction and project selection by eliminating individual formula factors and reducing the number of programs by two-thirds. This shift would be achieved by transferring program eligibility to core programs and restricting transferability between programs to 20% of each formula program's apportionment. Additionally, nearly all discretionary grant programs under FHWA control would be eliminated, with the Transportation Enhancements Program rolled into the CMAQ program. The bill also introduces a National Freight Program to enhance project delivery and eligibility requirements. The National Freight Program (NFP) aims to increase funding for freight projects by eliminating competition with non-freight projects. The Senate bill proposes a significant increase in funding for the Transportation Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act (TIFIA) program. However, there is limited mention of tolling on federally funded roads and bridges. H.R. 7 is a five-year reauthorization bill with modest increases for federal-aid highways and funding for research and education. The bill also consolidates existing programs into the National Highway System and Surface Transportation Programs, reducing the overall number of distinct programs. The Equity Bonus program would reduce the number of distinct programs to around 30 and guarantee a 94% state rate of return to the HTF. The Mass Transit Account would be renamed the Alternative Transportation Account, providing funding for mass transit and $2.267 billion annually for highway programs. Fuel taxes credited to the Mass Transit Account would be redirected to the Highway Account. Provisions under the streamlining title would change NEPA requirements for federal highway and transit projects. NEPA would no longer apply to projects costing less than $10 million or with federal funding constituting 15% or less of total costs. TIFIA funding would increase nearly ten-fold. A "solvency account" would be established to manage excess funds for the Highway Trust Fund. The Senate bill proposes using the LUST trust fund to generate revenue for the highway trust fund. The LUST trust fund was established in 1986 to address groundwater contamination from leaking underground storage tanks containing petroleum. It is funded by a tax on gasoline and diesel fuels and supports environmental contamination investigation and cleanup programs. The fund has been used by states to oversee corrective actions by responsible parties and conduct cleanup in emergencies. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 expanded its use for federal UST leak prevention and detection programs. Over 85% of reported releases have been addressed, leaving a backlog of 88,000. In FY2012, the LUST trust fund had an unobligated balance of $3.392 billion. Congress has appropriated approximately $113 million annually from the trust fund, with states receiving a minimum of 80% as grants. Section 40301 of the Senate bill proposes transferring $3.0 billion from the LUST trust fund to the highway trust fund in FY2012. Section 40302 suggests appropriating one-third of future LUST trust fund receipts from the gasoline and diesel fuel tax to the highway trust fund. The Senate bill proposes transferring funds from the LUST trust fund to the highway trust fund, with projections of annual transfers ranging from $62 million to $67 million. The bill also extends the LUST trust fund expenditure authority and reconfigures the highway trust fund, requiring future transfers to be fully offset in budget authority and outlays. The House bill, H.R. 7, aims to reconfigure the Highway Trust Fund by filling revenue gaps and proposing a new allocation of government receipts from energy leasing and production activities.
